Reckitt downgrades

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 6,959, down 76 (-1.08%), High: 7,097, Low: 6,846, Volume: 1.23m
PM11:13am

https://www.invest...1710180700038773T/

11:13 am
PM11:13am

RB not mincing words

PM11:13am

CHALLENGING ENVIRONMENT, REORGANISING FOR GROWTH

PM11:14am

Have some Investec

11:14 am
PM11:14am

They're sellers

PM11:14am

Reckitt’s Q3 sales are weak, at -1% (consensus +1%), with management lowering FY17 guidance again to flat lfl sales growth (cons: +1%) for the base; Mead guidance is unchanged (at -2% to 0%), but has benefited from stocking up in the US. The core Health OTC business (-2% vs cons +1%) is notably disappointing, and CEO Rakesh Kapoor will now assume direct responsibility for it. We think the recovery will be slower than the market expects. We remain at Sell.

PM11:15am

The market, and Reckitt itself, has slowly acknowledged current trading weakness and a deteriorating Health category (estimated at 3% currently by the company, vs 4-6% medium-term guidance which Reckitt expects to exceed). Scholl/Amope continued to be weak and the impact of the cyberattack in the quarter has been greater than initially anticipated – with a lingering impact expected in Q4 too. We consider OTC market weakness to be part structural.
Mead is on track, with the FY guidance of “-2% to flat” LFL unchanged. In Q3, Mead grew 1% (our estimate: -1%), but this has been flattered by stocking up in the US (which fell 3% due to negative pricing). In Asia (mainly China), Mead grew 4% (note that Danone in China grew 50% in this same period), thanks to a market which has accelerated and growth in its imported brands.
The new reporting structure of Health, headed by Mr Kapoor, and “Hygiene Home”, under Rob de Groot (current head of ENA), reflects the growing importance of this part of the business, but also perhaps growing concern on Mr Kapoor’s part that it needs a firm hand on the tiller in the current turbulence.

11:16 am
PM11:16am

Liberum are buyers

PM11:17am

RB’s call highlights that headwinds will persist in 4Q and likely into 2018. Management noted that overall pricing at group level turned negative in 3Q with group volumes flat. This marks further deterioration in the competitive landscape which RB expects will persist for a while longer. RB’s market growth rates remain subdued at 2% and the group is no longer outperforming and taking share. There are also lingering effects from supply chain disruptions related to the cyber-attack. The group's reorganization is held out as a means to affect sharper commercial focus and regain competitive edge. Yet the announcement at 3Q during what is usually a trading-focused release strikes us as a bit unusual, particularly given the lack of clarity on the guidance for higher fixed costs. While RB remains on track to deliver Mead cost savings, lower market growth and higher fixed costs look set to weigh on consensus expectations for 2018. We view RB as well-positioned to drive consolidation in Consumer Health via further M&A opportunities.

PM11:17am

Be a bit surprised if we saw any further M&A from RB myself

Foxtons Group PLC (FOXT:LSE): Last: 77.00, up 4 (+5.48%), High: 78.75, Low: 73.00, Volume: 800.81k
PM11:28am

Q3 were as expected i think

PM11:29am

I can get you one of those little UBS Q&As

11:29 am
PM11:29am

But it doesnt say a great deal

PM11:29am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?A: Q3 trading in-line, with group revenues of £35.1m, down -6% y-o -y. Cash flow remained strong, helped by the stable lettings performance. Our FY estimates imply H2-17 revenues down -6%, so Foxtons run-rate remains in-line with our forecasts.Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?A: Divisionally Foxtons reported sales revenues of £10.3m (down -16% y-o -y), lettings revenues of £22.5m (down -2% y-o -y) with downward pressure in rental rates in part offset by some volume improvement, and Alexander Hall at £2.3m (flat y-o -y).Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?A: No comment on the full year. The business is tracking in-line with expectations but limited forward visibility remains in sales particularly.Q: How would we expect investors to react?A: Statement in-line, with trends broadly a continuation of those flagged at the half year. The London market remains weak, with no evidence yet of market improvement

Commenting on the announcement, Michael Bruce, Group CEO, said:

"We are surprised by the ASA judgement on the flat fee wording because prior to air our adverts went through the proper approvals process, including the official clearance body Clearcast who have continued to support their original judgement with the ASA.

Purplebricks is firmly on the side of the consumer, offering an alternative to the commission based model. As a leader of industry change some noise is inevitable.

11:37 am
PM11:37am

Here's a par from Liberum

PM11:37am

Higher maintenance costs are a clear disappointment in the short term. We assume a £15m hit this year, which ought to be conservative and one-off. There ought to be a payback from improved reliability, which in turn should reduce passenger compensation and other disruption costs. The commercial performance appears encouraging, with improvements in both yields and load factors. However, until there is greater clarity on maintenance costs, along with further evidence of capacity cuts supporting better unit revenue trends, we believe the shares will struggle to perform. We downgrade our recommendation to HOLD from Buy, and cut our target price to 45p from 50p.

4) How strong can LEGOLAND Park LfL sales growth be next year with little support from movies and weakening toy sales?

PM11:44am

LfL sales grew 1.6% in 2016 after 13% in 2014 and 8% in 2015, and were +3.4% in the first 40 weeks of FY17 (but -1.3% in Q3). How large an impact was Hurricane Irma on the Florida park (we estimate 1%)? Is there still plenty of catch-up in Florida to get to California's trading levels? What was the impact of poor weather in Northern Europe?

PM11:45am

PM11:46am

Erm, Credit Suisse upgrading British Airways after the Delta figs

11:46 am
PM11:46am

IAG

PM11:46am

Delta commentary suggests 4Q consensus easily beaten: Factoring in
positive Delta commentary that 3Q unit revenue strength would accelerate
into 4Q on the Transatlantic, we raise our IAG EBIT 3% to €3,055m for
2017E and by 2% to €3,276m for 2018E, leaving us 5% and 9% ahead of
Bloomberg consensus, respectively. Our 3Q EBIT of €1,394m is in line with
consensus, highlighting that consensus implies a 4Q EBIT decline from
€620m in 4Q16 to €532m in 4Q17 - which seems highly unlikely given
Delta’s encouraging commentary. We re-iterate Outperform with a target
price of 721p (up 5%), suggesting 16% upside potential before compelling
cash distribution prospects given a 2017E FCF yield of 14%.

PM11:46am

Next six months about increasingly compelling ROIC and FCF
generation and distribution: IAG reported a 12-month ROIC of 15.1% to
June 2017, which is in line with its 2016-2020 target of 15%+ with BA already
at 15% and Aer Lingus 22%. We think management will look to raise this
target, reflecting further opportunity at British Airways (Heathrow full,
efficiency opportunities despite potential investment in premium cabin), top
line and opex opportunities at Iberia (LatAm and labour), Vueling back on a
surer footing, and Aer Lingus connecting traffic growth ambitions. We model
IAG generating €2bn in free cash flow in 2017E, a 14% projected FCF yield
(€2.7bn on IAG’s definition), and see this as fully distributable, suggesting a
potential uplift to the cumulative €1bn distribution announced with FY16

11:47 am
PM11:47am

They reckon the stock is 20% too cheap

PM11:47am

Valuation: IAG trades on a 2018E EV/IC of 1.4x on our numbers, versus a
ROIC/WACC of 2.2x. We highlight that on an EV/IC vs ROIC/WACC and an
EV/Sales vs EBITDAR margin basis, the stock’s EV looks 10% undervalued,
suggesting a c20% undervaluation of market cap.

PM11:49am

UBS been looking at online grocer

PM11:50am

And also Amazon on the back of the Wholefoods takeover

11:50 am
PM11:50am

They've had some call with an eCommerce expert, Tom Furphy

PM11:51am

Assume it's this chap http://consumerequ...ers.com/tom_furphy

PM11:51am

I havent had a chance to read this, but I know Amazon/Wholefoods is a big talking point

11:51 am
PM11:51am

So let me get you the highlights

PM11:52am

Incoming....

PM11:52am

A few of Tom's key insights from the call, many more in the replay belowQ. Why does Amazon want to be in grocery at all? It is a thin margin business, but Amazon wants to be the place where people find, discover and buy anything they want online. Customers' frequenting other retailers diminishes Amazon's value. Q. Why buy Whole Foods? Achieving drop-density from grocery fulfilment centres is challenging; wants in-market presence to get product closer to customers (pick-up can be more convenient than delivery). Good fit of brands and same 'customer obsession.'Q. Might Amazon run grocery as a zero margin business? Doesn’t have great tolerance for long-term loss, but break-even could make sense in totality of a model with adjacent profit opportunities (Prime subscription, data driven advertising, etc.). Q. Will Amazon open many brick and mortar stores? Doesn't expect buying spree;category by category approach to improving customer experience and driving loyalty; will stay asset light, nimble, agile. Future acquisitions must appeal to Prime customers. Q. What is the future for Amazon Go technology? Doesn’t expect major roll-out to Whole Foods boxes; technology could be launched as a platform to offer services to other retailers. Amazon will use various tech to target labour costs across the store. Q. Is Amazon friend or foe to FMCG players? Amazon's ownership of both data and platform (e.g. Alexa) is being leveraged to increase private label penetration (i.e. compete against branded players). At the same time it is also their fastest growing retail partner and some are heavily reliant on Amazon for eCommerce volumes. FMCG players must continue to innovate and create new products to retain relevance. Q. How will auto replenishment impact retail-supplier relationship? Retailers must develop replenishment/subscription tools to compete with Amazon (Dash, Alexa); manufacturers will support this as direct-to-consumer isn't practical (shoppers don’t want 20 subscriptions). Physical stores will remain key touch-points for brands.
